subject: Properly handle transport URL config on the client
commit_message:
Properly handle transport URL config on the client

On the client side, in the rabbit and qpid drivers, we use a connection
pool to avoid opening a connection for each message we send. However,
there is only currently one connection pool per process:

 def get_connection_pool(conf, connection_cls):
     with _pool_create_sem:
         # Make sure only one thread tries to create the connection pool.
         if not connection_cls.pool:
             connection_cls.pool = ConnectionPool(conf, connection_cls)
     return connection_cls.pool

This is a nasty artifact of the original RPC having no conectp of a
transport context - everything was a global. We'll fix this soon enough.

In the meantime, we need to make sure we only use this connection pool
where we're not using the default transport configuration from the
config file - i.e. where we supply a transport URL.

The use case here is cells - we send messages to a remote cell by
connecting to it using a transport URL. In our devstack testing, the
two cells are on the same Rabbit broker but under different virtual
hosts. Because we were always using the connection pool on the client
side, we were seeing both cells always send messages to the '/' virtual
host.

Note - avoiding the connection pool in the case of cells is the same
behaviour as the current RPC code:

 def cast_to_server(conf, context, server_params, topic, msg, connection_pool):
     ...
     with ConnectionContext(conf, connection_pool, pooled=False,
                            server_params=server_params) as conn:

operations to fail.

following way:
- KeyError on dict lookup failure results in empty string
- IndexError on list index results in empty string

subject: Add Config Options for Block Device Creation Timeout
commit_message:
Add Config Options for Block Device Creation Timeout

Upon creating a new block device, we await the device's creation,
polling every 1 second 60 times to see if the device has been created.
We want to be able to configure the polling interval and number of times
to poll before failing, since different environments could have different
time constraints.

Two configuration options have been added:
* poll_blk_dev_tries defines the maximum number of attempts before failing
* poll_blk_dev_interval defines the number of seconds between attempts

The defaults for these options are the old hard-coded values (60 and 1,
respectively).

subject: make libvirt driver get_connection thread-safe
commit_message:
make libvirt driver get_connection thread-safe

libvirt driver's get_connection is not thread safe in the
presence of a libvirtd restart during concurrent incoming
requests.

With existing code each will in turn call get_connection,
find the connection is broken, try to create new one, block
for a while and yield to the next thread to do the same.
You get as many connections as there are incoming requests
and only the last one is used finally. If enough are incoming
these connections can exhaust the client pool configured
for libvirtd.
One fix is to hold a lock while creating the connection.
Note that has_min_version calls _conn which calls get_connection
and thus the direct call to _has_min_version()

Also added the exception text if it fails to register an event
handler for lifecycle events.

Adopt 0.1.8 as iso8601 minimum version

In the images api, we depend on iso8601 to parse some dates and times.
Recently, since version 0.1.4, python-iso8601 added support for a few
more formats, and we finally got some other issues nailed down by 0.1.8.
If end user switch from 0.1.8 back to 0.1.4 in the deployment, the image
api will lose support for certain datetime formats like YYYY-MM-DD
(where the time part is assumed to be all zeros). This obviously creates
a compatibility concern.

We were resolved to make glance compatible with both iso 0.1.4 and
0.1.8, but it appears that to do so requires essentially reimplementing
a large swath of iso8601 0.1.8 in glance itself.

subject: Set OVS/enable_tunneling in the plugin, not only the agent
commit_message:
Set OVS/enable_tunneling in the plugin, not only the agent

It is wrong to assume (as the commit
8d0d9f3a4275649747cc50648f129c92e286def3 did) that that any node that
runs the OVS plugin will also run the corresponding plugin-specific
agent. It is perfectly feasible and supported to have an API node that
loads the OVS plugin, and which is distinct from compute and network
nodes that run the plugin-specific agent. If Neutron is configured for
GRE tunneling, then the API node (which runs the plugin), and the
network node and compute node (which run the agent) must all be
configured for tunneling.

Use ensure_resource to enable tunneling, regardless of whether the
plugin and agent nodes are separate or not.

Failure to enable tunneling on the node running neutron-server, while
setting $tenant_network_type = 'gre', will result in the following
error and render the Neutron API service inoperational:

ERROR neutron.plugins.openvswitch.ovs_neutron_plugin [-] Tunneling disabled but tenant_network_type is 'gre'. Server terminated!

subject: Allow user to specify instance resume behaviour on host reboot
commit_message:
Allow user to specify instance resume behaviour on host reboot

The configuration option resume_guests_state_on_host_boot defines
a global policy on whether or not to restart instances when a host
reboots.  Because a host may be down for a significant period of
time many cloud applications monitor their own instances and launch
replacements restarting all instances is rarely the required behaviour

The blueprint provides the user with a mechanism to specify the
resume policy on a per instance basis.

Supported values are:
  Default -  use system configuration value (current behaviour)
  Never   -  Don't resume this instance
  Always  -  Always resume this instance

This is the first part of the blueprint which implements the resume
decision.   The API extension will be provided in a separate commit

Code is structured to allow a futher option of "Resume only if host
has been down for less than xxx seconds" - but we need support from
the ServiceGroup API for that.

Partly implements bp: user-defined-resume

DocImpact
